name: 1,2-propadiene
Reason: The basic unit we can consider is ethylene (ethylene, C2H4), which has a melting point of -169.2°C. Propadiene (also known as allene) has an additional pi bond compared to ethylene. The introduction of additional pi bonding typically raises the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, which however is not as significant as sigma bond interactions. The addition of the extra carbon and pi bond could raise the melting point by an estimated +10°C due to increased molecular complexity and slight increase in van der Waals forces.

name: 1,2-propadiene
Reason: The basic unit to compare 1,2-propadiene to is ethylene (C2H4), which has a melting point of -169.2°C. Introducing an extra pi bond in 1,2-propadiene, compared to ethylene, increases the rigidity of the molecule and adds to the pi-pi interactions, which could result in a slightly higher melting point. However, the impact of an additional pi bond on the melting point is generally less than that of sigma bonds. Moreover, the linear structure of allene due to the presence of cumulated double bonds imposes less steric hindrance and packability improvements. An increase of approximately +30°C could be rationalized based on the cumulative effect of added molecular weight and pi-pi interactions.
